Precautions
Treatment

• Dietary changes: Increase fiber intake to soften stools and prevent straining.

• Topical treatments: Use over-the-counter creams, ointments, or suppositories to reduce pain, itching, and inflammation.

• Sclerotherapy or banding: In-office procedures to shrink hemorrhoids by cutting off their blood supply.

• Rubber band ligation: Place a rubber band around the base of the hemorrhoid to cut off its blood supply, causing it to shrink and fall off.

• Hemorrhoidectomy: Surgical removal of hemorrhoids for severe cases unresponsive to other treatments.

• Eat high-fiber foods: To soften stools.

• Stay hydrated and exercise regularly.

• Avoid prolonged sitting or standing: Take breaks.

• Use gentle, fragrance-free wipes Or soft toilet paper.

• Topical ointments or creams: Over-the-counter or prescription creams containing calcium channel blockers or nitroglycerin to relax the anal sphincter and promote healing.

• Sitz baths: Soak the anal area in warm water for 10-15 minutes several times a day to relieve pain and promote healing.

• Dietary changes: Increase fiber intake and drink plenty of water to soften stools and reduce strain during bowel movements.

• Botulinum toxin injection: Injections into the anal sphincter to relax the muscle and promote healing in chronic fissures.

• Surgical sphincterotomy: In severe or chronic cases, a surgical procedure to cut the internal anal sphincter muscle to reduce spasm and promote healing.

• Maintain a high-fiber diet: And drink plenty of water to prevent constipation.

• Practice good anal hygiene: Avoid excessive wiping or harsh cleansers.

• Use stool softeners or topical ointments: As recommended by a healthcare professional to promote healing.

• Avoid straining during bowel movements: Consider using a stool or footstool to elevate your feet while on the toilet to ease passage.

• Incision and drainage: If the sinus is infected, a healthcare provider may need to make an incision to drain pus and debris from the abscess.

• Antibiotics: In cases of infection, antibiotics may be prescribed to treat the bacterial infection.

• Laser hair removal or shaving: To prevent recurrence, hair removal methods may be used to reduce hair in the affected area.

• Surgical excision: For recurrent or chronic cases, surgical removal of the sinus tract and surrounding tissue may be necessary.

• Maintain good hygiene: Especially in the buttock area.

• Keep the area clean and dry: To prevent bacterial growth.

• Avoid prolonged sitting: Or pressure on the affected area.

• Seek medical attention: If symptoms persist or worsen.

• Incision and Drainage: Drain the abscess surgically to relieve pain and prevent further infection.

• Seton Placement: Insert a thread-like material into the fistula tract to keep it open and allow for continuous drainage.

• Fistulotomy: Cut open the entire length of the fistula tract to remove it completely.

• Fistulectomy: Surgically remove the entire fistula tract, possibly including surrounding tissue.

• LIFT Procedure: Identify and ligate the internal opening of the fistula tract while preserving the anal sphincter muscles.

• Advancement Flap Repair: Use tissue from the inside of the rectum to cover and close the internal opening of the fistula.

• Fibrin Glue Injection: Inject fibrin glue into the fistula tract to seal it off and promote healing.

• Biological Plugs: Use biological plugs made from materials such as porcine collagen to seal the internal opening of the fistula.

• Antibiotics: Prescribe antibiotics to treat or prevent infection.

• Maintain good anal hygiene: Keep the area clean and dry to prevent infection and irritation.

• Avoid prolonged sitting: Or pressure on the anal region to reduce discomfort and prevent exacerbation of symptoms.

• Seek medical attention: If you experience persistent pain, swelling, or drainage from an opening near the anus.

• Follow healthcare provider recommendations: For treatment, which may include antibiotics, surgical drainage, or surgical removal of the fistula tract.
